text:
Haven't started publishing yet, but ours will be a combo of

1. me (Content Lead) upcycling internal memos into thought leadership content. Our team has a pretty strong documentation/memo culture and there's tons of gold in there.
2. our team writing and me amping them up a bit
3. me interviewing people over a call and then ghostwriting for them

text:
Hi everyone!

I'm being asked to create my OKRs around traffic numbers. I.e. X number of visitors for the year/quarter.

How does one come up with this number?

The boss is leaning towards "this year's traffic times 2" but has asked me to set an intimidating goal for us. If there's one thing I've learned about SEO in the last 2 years is that it's my weakest "content muscle" and I'm naturally averse to guessing, so I'm struggling with this.

This is for a nonprofit, so there are no sales goals etc. to hang my hat on when doing this analysis.

elements.text:
Hi everyone!

I'm being asked to create my OKRs around traffic numbers. I.e. X number of visitors for the year/quarter.

How does one come up with this number?

The boss is leaning towards "this year's traffic times 2" but has asked me to set an intimidating goal for us. If there's one thing I've learned about SEO in the last 2 years is that it's my weakest "content muscle" and I'm naturally averse to guessing, so I'm struggling with this.

This is for a nonprofit, so there are no sales goals etc. to hang my hat on when doing this analysis.

text:
I've found that it's safe to say you will rank for 7-10% of the total volume you've developed high quality content for within 12 months. So, if you've got 10 pages targeting a total of 1M volume per month, you'll likely end up with 70K-100K hits/month to those pages.

The numbers average out best the more pages you have.

Also, I would try to encourage le boss to think about OKRs in terms of the final result. Without a product, I'm guessing you've got an email list, or get donations, or have people sign up to volunteer, maybe?

You'll probably fare better with those end goals if you're targeting smaller, more bottom-of-funnel keywords, just like any other business would. There may not be a super easy way to track these things, but I'd try to focus on basically ANY goal other than just raw traffic (if possible). That's the kind of goal that will lead to building content that's optimized just for lots of eyes, but not necessarily to meet any real business targets.

I hope that's helpful!!

EDIT: Looking at Upsolve's website, I'd even see if you can set a goal for improving the number of "go to free bankruptcy tool" clicks you get.

elements.text:

The numbers average out best the more pages you have.

Also, I would try to encourage le boss to think about OKRs in terms of the final result. Without a product, I'm guessing you've got an email list, or get donations, or have people sign up to volunteer, maybe?

You'll probably fare better with those end goals if you're targeting smaller, more bottom-of-funnel keywords, just like any other business would. There may not be a super easy way to track these things, but I'd try to focus on basically ANY goal other than just raw traffic (if possible). That's the kind of goal that will lead to building content that's optimized just for lots of eyes, but not necessarily to meet any real business targets.

I hope that's helpful!!

EDIT: Looking at Upsolve's website, I'd even see if you can set a goal for improving the number of "go to free bankruptcy tool" clicks you get.

text: It's possible, I think, but it's not really a target. For instance, is the volume and potential traffic you're targeting actually the same as what you targeted last year? Unless you're comparing a 12-month period with identical target search volume, that's not really a way to set a goal that makes sense (IMHO). So yes, you're doing great!

text: All me for the writing. The team repurposes/distributes. They also help with idea development. But for the really big stuff like books, it is all me.

text: Huge proponent of interviewing the thought leaders, transcribing, and using that to start several pieces. I've been a one-woman team, lead a global content team, and now head marketing at a fast growing start-up and this method has worked and scaled with me. It also made it easy to create outlines and provide snippets to ghost writers as necessary, write internally, or even helped my thought leaders turn their interview into better written content. It's very hard to wrangle even the most dedicated leader to sit and write, but they usually can spare some time to answer some questions that, for a writer, would be a wealth of knowledge!

It's very hard to wrangle even the most dedicated leader to sit and write, but they usually can spare some time to answer some questions that, for a writer, would be a wealth of knowledge!

text: I am amazed. So many people have the same issue with their VP/CMO/CEO. The concept of a quick win and instant result is really dominant in the community. One of my clients for example runs an e-commerce business. I have a problem explaining that articles that are too many sales-oriented won't produce tangible results. For some reason, some CEOs don't see past that. Articles that create genuine value for the reader will always bring long-term results.
